text.p: The chairman of Italy's Finmeccanica Fabiano Fabiani on Wednesday confirmed his resignation from the defence and engineering group after a clash with its majority shareholder, the state holding IRI.
Fabiani was speaking at the group's annual shareholders meeting which approved the group's 1996 results by a large majority.
"I am not able to accept the IRI statement, which I consider harmful to the position of the chairman and to my personal image," he told shareholders.

Fabiani said last week that he would resign at the meeting after an IRI statement late on Thursday announcing a radical shake up of the group, which many analysts took as a condemnation of the current management.

The IRI shake-up finally signalled the end of Italian hopes that Finmeccanica could be built up into an Italian defence and engineering conglomerate, and the new structure would create a nimbler group to pursue vital European defence alliances.
Finmeccanica made a 540.4 billion lire loss in 1996 after 575 billion lire of extraordinary charges, and IRI's original plan for Finmeccancia's privatisation in 1997 look optimistic.
